awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Detection of Strep Throat on a Telehealth Visit using Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Smartphone Images
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of telehealth technology that shifts the care delivery model from in-person to virtual. Despite the wealth of recent medical artificial intelligence (AI) literature, few forms of AI translate from a theoretical context into clinical practice. The proposed technology enhances AI performance with novel, deep learning techniques, evaluates the usability and interpretability of an AI medical test in clinical practice, and measures whether use of the AI test alters antibiotic prescribing practices. This research may expand the knowledge around AI-based clinical decision support software used in clinical practice. Improved access to virtual healthcare can impact those who are most vulnerable, such as the underserved, those who lack transportation, those who have disabilities, or tjpse who have chronic illness. For example, if each of the 40 million strep throat visits were performed on telehealth instead of emergency rooms or urgent cares, health insurers could save $4-12 billion/year.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a novel, deep learning algorithm that predicts strep throat using a smartphone video of the throat. It is currently feasible to detect strep throat from a smartphone photo by using pattern recognition of the tonsils and basic machine learning. However, the current technologies use high quality, single frame images that are impractical to acquire in a moving patient, or they use hardware not easily accessible to patients at home. A new approach is to use smartphone video for machine learning. Furthermore, there are visual changes unique to strep throat, such as redness or pus on the tonsils, that doctors can only identify with 55% accuracy. This technology applies pattern recognition of these visual changes to differentiate smartphone images of streptococcal pharyngitis (strep throat) from viral pharyngitis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This report presents the findings and implications from conducting 160 customer discovery interviews during the NSF I-Corps program. This program focused on understanding telehealth practices and their challenges with point-of-care tests. The study reveals a significant pain point for telehealth providers: the need for effective solutions to facilitate screening tests at home for their patients. Additionally, the report highlights the business models of telehealth practices and Electronic Health Record (EHR) vendors, providing insights into the evolving landscape of healthcare delivery.

 

The rapid growth of telehealth has transformed healthcare delivery, offering patients remote access to medical services. However, the integration of diagnostic testing, particularly point-of-care tests, remains a challenge. To better understand this issue, a series of 160 customer discovery interviews were conducted with telehealth providers. The objective was to identify their pain points and explore potential solutions to enhance patient care.

 

The key findings were as follows:

  1. Pain Point - Point of Care Tests:
    • Telehealth practices reported a significant pain point in providing point-of-care tests to patients remotely, especially for strep throat
    • The lack of efficient mechanisms for patients to receive and perform screening tests at home hinders the diagnostic process, leading to delays in treatment and reduced patient satisfaction.
    • Current alternatives are sending patients to a local urgent care or medical practice, or facilitating a home delivery kit.
  2. Demand for Solutions:
    • There is a clear demand among telehealth providers for innovative solutions that enable patients to easily access and perform screening tests from the comfort of their homes.
    • Solutions that seamlessly integrate with telehealth platforms and provide accurate, timely results are highly sought after.

 

The study's findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the challenges faced by telehealth practices in incorporating point-of-care tests. By identifying the specific pain points and needs of these providers, researchers and entrepreneurs can focus their efforts on developing targeted solutions that enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of telehealth services. This research also lays the groundwork for future studies on the integration of diagnostic testing in remote healthcare delivery.

 

Future implications to solve for this problem can:

  1. Improve Patient Care:
    • Solutions that address the identified pain point have the potential to significantly improve patient care by enabling timely diagnosis and treatment, leading to better health outcomes.
  2. Increase Accessibility:
    • By facilitating at-home screening tests, telehealth services can become more accessible to patients in remote or underserved areas, reducing healthcare disparities.
  3. Business Model Innovation:
    • The findings highlight the need for innovation in the business models of telehealth practices and EHR vendors. Telehealth practices must adapt to incorporate diagnostic testing solutions, while EHR vendors need to ensure seamless integration with these new tools.

 

The customer discovery interviews have shed light on a critical challenge in the telehealth sector: the need for effective point-of-care testing solutions. Addressing this pain point is essential for enhancing patient care and expanding the reach of telehealth services. As the healthcare industry continues to evolve, the insights gained from this study will be invaluable in guiding the development of innovative solutions and business models that meet the needs of both providers and patients.

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2024
Modified by: Keith Kleinman
por.por_txt_cntn:
This report presents the findings and implications from conducting 160 customer discovery interviews during the NSF I-Corps program. This program focused on understanding telehealth practices and their challenges with point-of-care tests. The study reveals a significant pain point for telehealth providers: the need for effective solutions to facilitate screening tests at home for their patients. Additionally, the report highlights the business models of telehealth practices and Electronic Health Record (EHR) vendors, providing insights into the evolving landscape of healthcare delivery.





The rapid growth of telehealth has transformed healthcare delivery, offering patients remote access to medical services. However, the integration of diagnostic testing, particularly point-of-care tests, remains a challenge. To better understand this issue, a series of 160 customer discovery interviews were conducted with telehealth providers. The objective was to identify their pain points and explore potential solutions to enhance patient care.





The key findings were as follows:

Pain Point - Point of Care Tests: 

Telehealth practices reported a significant pain point in providing point-of-care tests to patients remotely, especially for strep throat
The lack of efficient mechanisms for patients to receive and perform screening tests at home hinders the diagnostic process, leading to delays in treatment and reduced patient satisfaction.
Current alternatives are sending patients to a local urgent care or medical practice, or facilitating a home delivery kit.


Demand for Solutions: 

There is a clear demand among telehealth providers for innovative solutions that enable patients to easily access and perform screening tests from the comfort of their homes.
Solutions that seamlessly integrate with telehealth platforms and provide accurate, timely results are highly sought after.








The study's findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the challenges faced by telehealth practices in incorporating point-of-care tests. By identifying the specific pain points and needs of these providers, researchers and entrepreneurs can focus their efforts on developing targeted solutions that enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of telehealth services. This research also lays the groundwork for future studies on the integration of diagnostic testing in remote healthcare delivery.





Future implications to solve for this problem can:

Improve Patient Care: 

Solutions that address the identified pain point have the potential to significantly improve patient care by enabling timely diagnosis and treatment, leading to better health outcomes.


Increase Accessibility: 

By facilitating at-home screening tests, telehealth services can become more accessible to patients in remote or underserved areas, reducing healthcare disparities.


Business Model Innovation: 

The findings highlight the need for innovation in the business models of telehealth practices and EHR vendors. Telehealth practices must adapt to incorporate diagnostic testing solutions, while EHR vendors need to ensure seamless integration with these new tools.








The customer discovery interviews have shed light on a critical challenge in the telehealth sector: the need for effective point-of-care testing solutions. Addressing this pain point is essential for enhancing patient care and expanding the reach of telehealth services. As the healthcare industry continues to evolve, the insights gained from this study will be invaluable in guiding the development of innovative solutions and business models that meet the needs of both providers and patients.
